title: Breach Risk Under Vaccine Efficacy Scenarios
text:
Figure 1: Breach risk across transmissibility levels.





Booming various kinds of SARS-CoV-2 viruses have put much pressure on the original isolation system because of their high transmissibility.
Q1: How does VE change breach risk under a fixed quarantine system?
Q2: How does higher transmissibility shift that risk?
The whole article is answering these two questions.
We focus on a hotel-based system with a defined testing schedule and isolation rules, and we quantify performance by breach events—instances where an infectious traveller or quarantine worker has uncontrolled contact with the public.The article reported breaches per 1,000 arrivals and the 30-day probability of at least one outbreak, judging success when both remain below a predefined threshold.



To address Q1, we vary VE from low to high while holding the protocol fixed, then estimate breaches/1000 and 30-day break out probability.






Figure 2: Breach risk across transmissibility levels.



As shown in Figure 2, breach risk decrease as VE rises; importantly, the decline is non-linear beyond moderate VE. This figure answers Q1 by showing that higher VE substantially reduces breach pressure, but does not eliminate it.






Figure 3: Outbreak-free time vs vaccine efficacy.



Building on this, for Q2 the article increased the transmissibilitiy while keeping VE and protocal constant. As the Figure 3 show, we could see that more transmissible variants erode the safety margin, so quarantine alone cannot compensate without strong vaccination and tight operations.



Generally speaking, Breach risk falls with VE and rises with the transmissibility of the virus. Vaccination can meaningfully counteracts variant pressure, yet stringent quarantine remains necessary for vaccinated travellers.



For reopening policies, combining high community vaccination with tight quarantine controls help keep the breach rates and 30-day outbreak probability under target.
If arrival prevalence spikes or a variant with substantially higher transmissibility emerges, today’s threshold can not meet the requirements. Next step, Track variant characteristics, re-calibate test schedules, and reestimate risk monthly.



1.Zachreson, C., Shearer, F. M., Price, D. J., Lydeamore, M. J., McVernon, J., McCaw, J., & Geard, N. (2022). COVID-19 in low-tolerance border quarantine systems: Impact of the Delta variant of SARS-CoV-2. Science Advances, 8(14), eabm3624. https://doi.org/10.1126/sciadv.abm3624

title: About
text:
I am now a master of Business Analytics in Monash University. I have learnt how to catch wild data, communicate with data, and data visualization….. I confirm that these skills could equip me for future careers.
I have got my bachelor degree in Shan Dong University in China. My major was international finance and trade. On that days, I have learnt about the practices about international trades and some academic basis.
I love coding and computer games. When i am energetic, I like to scratch the github for something interesting to equip my laptop. When i am tired, an exciting game will refresh me. I master python and R. I like dogs cause i think they are lovely and the symbol of loyalty.
